description: From Middle English onerous, from Middle French onereux, from Old French onereus, from Latin onerosus (“burdensome”), from onus (“load”).

adjectives.description: onerous (comparative more onerous, superlative most onerous)

entries.meaning: imposing or constituting a physical, mental, or figurative load which can be borne only with effort; burdensome.
examples: That all this might not be too onerous on the purses of his rustic patrons, who are apt to consider the costs of schooling a grievous burden, and schoolmasters as mere drones, he had various ways of rendering himself both useful and agreeable.
